newsitem.title: AFGHANISTAN: Strategic Afghan tunnel held by warlord Dostum.
newsitem.headline: Strategic Afghan tunnel held by warlord Dostum.

text.p: The Afghan faction led by Uzbek warlord General Abdul Rashid Dostum controls a strategic road tunnel northwest of the Afghan capital Kabul, a faction spokesman said on Tuesday.

"Our forces moved forward three or four days ago and took positions abandoned by the government (of deposed President Burnahuddin Rabbani) around the tunnel," Jumbish-i-Milli faction spokesman General Mohammed Yusef told reporters.

The tunnel, 70 km (45 miles) northwest of Kabul, is situated on the Salang highway, a key road linking Kabul to northern Afghanistan and the Central Asian republics beyond. It is part of a crucial link between Afghanistan and the outside world.
South of the tunnel lies the town of Jabal-us-Siraj, which was seized by the Islamic Taleban movement on Monday in its push north from the capital Kabul.
Yusef said there was no fighting around the tunnel and that it was completely under the control of Jumbish -- the National Islamic Movement of Afghanistan.
The territories in northern Afghanistan controlled by Jumbish have been tense ever since the radical Islamic Taleban militia seized Kabul last Friday.
"We don't want to fight, we've never fought the Taleban," Yusef said. "We are open to negotiations, we're ready to talk to them (the Taleban)."
Dostum's faction has for the most part kept a nervous silence ever since the Taleban's lightning move on Kabul.
Dostum holds the largest chunk of territory in Afghanistan outside Taleban control.
But the two factions have little in common.
Dostum's overwhelmingly Uzbek faction is relatively liberal compared to the radical Taleban, a movement made up mostly of Pashtuns from southern Afghanistan.
The Taleban have introduced strict Islamic law in the regions they control, ordering government employees to grow beards within one and a half months and banning women from the workplace.
Women in the bustling centre of Mazar-i-Sharif, a relatively wealthy Afghan town, have expressed concern that Taleban could enter their area.
"We would have to live at home like slaves, we could not even go to the bazaar," Isabel, a 22-year-old student of English at the university said on Monday.
